radiographic_examinations.findings: Mixed lytic-sclerotic lesion spanning the length of the radius, with expansion of the radial head, neck, and entire diaphysis. No obvious cortical disruption, periosteal reaction, or fracture.
4.5 Â· 5-cm expansile mass replacing the radial head and neck. The mass demonstrated bright enhancement, along with surrounding soft tissues and periosteum.
No obvious metastatic lesions in the lungs. A benign-appearing lytic lesion with a sclerotic margin detected in the right scapular neck, considered another focus of fibrous dysplasia.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: An incompletely visualized small fluid-density lesion in the supraspinatus muscle remained unchanged on a repeated CT scan two months later.

radiographic_examinations.findings: Mixed lytic-sclerotic lesion of the right humeral neck, extending to the mid-diaphysis with similar smaller lesions in the glenoid and acromion.
Additional, discontinuous soft-tissue masses in the shoulder girdle consistent with myxomas, with lesions in the humerus and scapula consistent with fibrous dysplasia.
Some resorption of the graft proximally; radial head and hardware remained in good position.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: Patient beginning to experience mild pain and tenderness at the radiocapitellar joint.
